image.altText: an orange map with faces of northern territory people popping out

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory has the highest proportion of Indigenous people out of all the states and territories. This is what they think of the Voice to Parliament referendum.

title.children: In NT towns where news travels via 'bush telegraph', here's what people say about the Voice

image.altText: a man wearing swimmers sits on the side of a harbour pool in sydney while looking at this phone

props.synopsis: The ABC's national weather wrap is back, as our meteorologist Tom Saunders breaks down why the declaration of El Niño and a positive Indian Ocean Dipole doesn't guarantee a dry summer.

title.children: Ready for round two? El Niño and positive Indian Ocean Dipole to deliver more spring heat

image.altText: A portrait of Troy Hunt in greyscale with only the Gold Coast skyline reflection in his sunglasses in colour

props.synopsis: He's just "a dude on the web", but Troy Hunt has ended up playing an oddly central role in global cybersecurity.

title.children: Troy scours the dark web for your stolen data — but he's just trying to help

image.altText: A composite image of Malcolm Turnbull, Rupert Murdoch and Kevin Rudd

props.synopsis: It's a well worn path for Australian prime ministers to meet with the world's most powerful person while in the United States. They also usually meet with the US president, writes Brett Worthington.

title.children: The mogul and the powerful men who court him: How Murdoch maintained a grip on Australian politics

image.altText: A close up photo of Natasha Fyles with a serious expression

props.synopsis: Natasha Fyles has taken aim at "attention-seeking senators" for criticising the $1.5 billion taxpayer-funded Middle Arm industrial hub, in a speech to the territory's business community.

title.children: 'Senators on a soapbox': NT chief minister slams Middle Arm industrial hub opponents

image.altText: Huge plumes of smoke from a bushfire rising about bushland.

props.synopsis: The 37-year-old man has been arrested and charged with lighting 18 bushfires in the NT's Top End region, with police trying to establish if he was connected to more than 60 others.

title.children: Alleged arsonist charged with deliberately lighting 18 blazes during extreme NT bushfire season

image.altText: A pool toy floating in a backyard pool.

props.synopsis: Coroner Elisabeth Armitage is recommending the Northern Territory government update its swimming pool safety laws, following the drowning death of a two-year-old.

title.children: 'Children deserve better': NT coroner releases findings on toddler's drowning

image.altText: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, left, and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau arrive at a signing ceremony.

props.synopsis: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy offers a heartfelt thanks to Canada for its help in the war against Russia, saying Ottawa's aid had helped save thousands of lives.

title.children: Zelenskyy speaks in Canada after Ukraine strikes Russia's navy base in Crimea

image.altText: A group of Collingwood AFL players stand with arms raised in triumph after the final siren in a finals game.

props.synopsis: The Magpies emerge victorious after a preliminary final for the ages, beating the Giants by a single point in front of more than 97,000 fans at the MCG.

title.children: Collingwood into the grand final after incredible one-point prelim win over GWS

image.altText: A group of rugby league players celebrate a try

props.synopsis: With the Panthers gearing up for yet another premiership, Ivan Cleary's side should be eyeing a place among the greatest teams ever to play their sport.

title.children: One more win and Penrith can lay claim as the greatest team in rugby league's history

image.altText: Two rugby league players face off during a match

props.synopsis: Referee Adam Gee lays down the law early in the NRL preliminary final, before the Panthers lay down a smashing of the Melbourne Storm as Penrith made a fourth-straight NRL grand final.

title.children: Five quick hits — lines were drawn, mistakes were made, and the Panthers are in the grand final

image.altText: A woman looking at her kindle

props.synopsis: As China's economy remains in the doldrums, more and more young people see social media influencer as a legitimate career option, but experts question the industry's sustainability.

title.children: Rainbow quit her job to become a full-time social media influencer and now earns up to $20,000 a month

image.altText: Qantas Group CEO Vanessa Hudson wearing a yellow top with trees behind her in public apology video

props.synopsis: Qantas' new CEO issues a public apology for a series of scandals that have damaged the airline's reputation, acknowledging it has been "hard to deal with" and promising to make changes to rebuild customer trust.

title.children: New Qantas boss publicly apologises for letting travelling public down

image.altText: A woman holds her stomach which has a baby in it and leans on a tree.

props.synopsis: Working full-time, recently married and pregnant, Maria and her partner never thought they wouldn't be able to find a home. But amid the rental crisis that's plaguing Australia, living in a tent was their only option.

title.children: Maria came from Colombia with big dreams of Australia. Now she's pregnant and living in a tent near Darwin

image.altText: An US senator wearing black suit and blue tie surrounded by people.

props.synopsis: US Senator Bob Menendez of New Jersey and his wife were indicted Friday on charges they took bribes of cash, gold bars and a luxury car for a range of corrupt acts.

title.children: US Senator Bob Menendez and wife charged with bribery as probe finds $154,000 in gold bars

image.altText: a young boy smiling at the camera while sitting down outdoors and holding a sippy cup

props.synopsis: An inquest into the disappearance of missing toddler William Tyrrell will continue early next year after a three-year adjournment with prosecutors expected to decide whether to charge his foster mother.

title.children: Prosecutors to advise on evidence for charges over William Tyrrell's suspected death within months

image.altText: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price speaks at a podium at the National Press Club

props.synopsis: No campaigner Jacinta Nampijinpa Price told the National Press Club last week there are no ongoing negative impacts of colonisation on Indigenous Australians. RMIT ABC Fact Check takes a look.

title.children: We fact checked Jacinta Nampijinpa Price on the negative impacts of colonisation. Here's what we found

image.altText: Lachlan and Sarah Murdoch at a red carpet event.

props.synopsis: Lachlan is set to become News Corp chairman and continue as chief executive officer of Fox Corp.

title.children: Lachlan Murdoch is now at the helm of his father's business. What do we know about his rise?

image.altText: Sylvie Ayer Conservation (Hope) Photographer of the Year winner

props.synopsis: An image of a paper nautilus — a type of octopus — floating on a piece of ocean debris comes out on top of 8,000 entries.

title.children: Dugongs, sharks and a 'paper nautilus' — the winning images from the Ocean Photographer of the Year competition

image.altText: Katy Gallagher raising her hand during a press conference.

props.synopsis: The finance minister has defended the scope of the newly announced inquiry into the response to COVID-19, despite chairing an inquiry herself that previously recommended a royal commission.

title.children: Federal government defends COVID inquiry as lockdowns locked out of scope

image.altText: Scientific image of COVID-19.

props.synopsis: Here's a quick wrap of the COVID-19 news and case numbers from each Australian jurisdiction from the past week.

title.children: All the latest COVID-19 case numbers from around Australia

image.altText: photo of drugs in hidden door in floor

props.synopsis: Photos shared by police show bags full of fentanyl inside a "trap floor" just a few steps away from a shelf of children's toys.

title.children: New York police find trapdoor hiding drugs at daycare centre where 1yo died after opioid exposure

image.altText: A photo of a woman laughing in a hospital bed with her son and daughter next to her

props.synopsis: The former nurse was diagnosed with an aggressive form of motor neurone disease and given months to live. Her dying wish was to save lives — and she did in an Australian first.

title.children: Minutes before she died, Ballarat nurse Marlene found out she would save four lives

image.altText: A ribbon bound version of Australia's constitution with a photo of the Australian outback in the background.

props.synopsis: Australia will vote on whether to make a change to its constitution next month. But what is this document? And what is the proposed change? We break it down for you here, and show you what the constitution would look like if the Voice referendum is passed.

title.children: Here's how the Australian Constitution would change if the Voice referendum is passed

image.altText: Police stand along a road

props.synopsis: A man dies in hospital after being shot by police during a confrontation in an alleyway in WA's Goldfields

title.children: Man shot by police in Kalgoorlie alleyway dies in hospital

image.altText: Rupert Murdoch and Jerry Hall sit, surrounded by their children, all the women holding bouquets

props.synopsis: Rupert Murdoch always wanted his media empire to stay in the family, but he could never commit to an heir. Despite having six children, only three were ever considered viable successors.

title.children: With Rupert Murdoch going, his children have a chessboard of potential moves to make

image.altText: Rupert Murdoch gestures with both hands while speaking.

props.synopsis: Rupert Murdoch's retirement is a momentous media moment that could lead to big shifts in the media and political landscapes in Australia and other parts of the English-speaking world.

title.children: The world's biggest press baron is handing over power. How will it affect media in Australia and abroad?

image.altText: a woman in front of a sold sign out the front of an apartment block with a real estate agent

props.synopsis: Almost one in six sellers in Sydney's high-construction neighbourhoods are losing money, some as much as $100,000 for their lifetime investment, with interest rate squeeze pushing buyers to sell up for a loss.

title.children: Ella's story of selling a Sydney unit for a $90,000 loss will make you think twice about entering the housing market

image.altText: A crowd of protesters, some wearing hats and sunglasses, holding picketing signs about the SAG-AFTRA strike

props.synopsis: If the Writers Guild of America strike continues to October, it will be the longest Hollywood strike since 1945.

title.children: 'It has to be worth it': Hollywood strike to continue as two days of negotiations fail
